results.description:
*INDOOR, FUTSAL OR SNEAKERS ONLY*

                           NO CLEATS or PLACTIC STUDS!

CO-ED FULL FIELD SOCCER GAME@ RIVERSIDE Park!

                         See our page on Facebook!:

                   ManhattanInternationalCoedSoccer

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W-iepwvf5Bg

DESCRIPTION:

Our games are for levels and people that prefer to play a competitive game of soccer, break a sweat while exercising running up and down the field with the ball and all this happening in a very laid-back and non-judgmental environment. Please, arrive 10 minutes before the game so we can get the teams set up.

There will be 2 teams on the field and we will play TWO games, 30 minutes/Halves. At the end of the first 30 minutes we will have a short break and teams will switch to play again. Please check your email or our meetup message board on friday night or before 12.00pm on Saturday to see what team you are on. This will save us a lot of time on the field.

RULES OF THE GAME:

First and most important rule of the game is to have fun and enjoy the time on the field! Rough play and offensive language will absolutely not be tolerated!!! In plain words, no slide tackling, no pushing and no telling off.

Power shots allowed, just please don't do it 5 feet away from goal.

If you don't sign up for the game, do not show up.

If you are late for the game, you must wait until the game in progress is over to join your team.

Those that don't comply with these rules, will kindly be asked to leave the field so others can enjoy the game and maybe a two game ban.

Any other questions regarding the rules of the game or anything else, should be directed to the organizer directly or to the assistant organizer/s!!!

Location:

Riverside Park at West 107 & 108 Street

Take the 1 RED Line Train to Cathedral Pkwy an walk two blocks down, to 108th Street and Riverside Dr.

The field is down the lower level near the river. You can easly access the field from 108th Street. Remember, the field is not visable from the street level, you have to walk down the stairs from Riverside Dr & 108th Street. and you will see the newly renovated fanced-in soccer field next to the river.

Call me if you can’t find the field - [masked] Manny S.


What to bring with you:

A pair of sneakers, indoor or turf shoes, shin guards (recommended) and lots of water. There is a water fountain next to the park if you need extra water.

Fee:

You will be asked to pay $9.25 when you RSVP. This $9.25 is used to pay for, facilities permits, meetup fees, Amazon fees, goals, cones, soccer balls etc.

Refunds & Weather Policy:

Refunds will be issued if the RSVP is changed by Wednesday before 12.00PM or if the game is cancelled. The game can be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe like heavy rain, snow or thunder.

After the game we'll head to a local bar for brunch and a Pint or Two.

Lion’s Head Tavern


995 Amsterdam Ave

New York, NY 10025

(212)[masked]

PARTICIPATING IN MANHATTAN-INTERNATIONAL-COED-SOCCER ACTIVITIES AGREEMENT:

I certify that I have no known medical or other conditions that could interfere with my participation in Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer activities. I also understand and accept that the practice of soccer, both indoor and outdoor, involves certain risks of physical injury. Therefore, I, individually, hereby release and discharge, Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer Organizer and Assistant Organizers from any and all claims, actions, damages, losses, liabilities, costs and expenses of any kind whatsoever, including but not limited to any claims of negligence, arising out of, resulting from, by reason of, or in connection with my participation in any of Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer programs or activities. Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer Organizer and its Assistant Organizers reserve the right to take and utilize photographs, video, or any type of recording of participating person while engaged in our or associated activities. I consent to Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer use the photograph, video, or recording of me, for advertising, promotional, or related purposes, and waive all rights to compensation and other rights which may arise as a result.

results.description:
PADDLES UP!!  Intro to Dragon Boat Paddling.

Every Saturday we welcome new members to try out this new sport of Dragon Boating. No experience needed; coaching, training and all equipment supplied.

If this is your first time trying this sport out, the cost is free.  If you already attended our " Free intro to Dragon Boating" on May 2nd and May 9th, the cost is $10 per session.  However, the fee is applied to the season membership fee of $100 if you become a member of "Team Dragon".  Full time College or High School Student Fee is only $35.  Membership comes with unlimited Dragon Boat practices/training every Thursday 6-8pm, every Saturday 10-12am and all events hosted by the NJ Dragon Boat Club at Lake Parsippany.  The season runs from April to September.

To become a season member, go to njdragonboat.org and complete the online registration.

Come out and give it a try and get a great work out!

Expect to meet new friends and enjoy the beautiful Lake!  Please wear appropriate clothing (no jeans), footwear, and sunblock as you may get a little wet from paddling. Bring a bottle of water to rehydrate. 

Please park on the side streets and not in the boat house parking lot.

Please complete and bring this WAIVER (linked) for each individual.

In the event of inclement weather. Please check this site at 8:30am Saturday morning to see if the event is cancelled.

results.description:
Here's Our Schedule: (Times are approximate.) 

10:00 - Welcome 

10:15 - Show & Tell - We show things we've made since the last meeting or before and ask for help with any problems we might have encountered.

11:15-11:30 - Break for refreshments.

11:30 -12:00 - Demo begins

1:00 - Meeting usually ends

$3.00 fee goes toward the cost of listing the meetings on this Meetup site.

Supply List - 


This is a demonstration on how the accuquilt works and why quilters find it a handy tool for cutting out their block pieces.  I will also provide instructions for making  a table runner.

After the demonstration everyone is welcome to cut out blocks for a project.  I thought we could do a small table runner that requires enough material for 12 -  7x7" squares of a heavier fabric (I used old recycled jeans - need about 3 pairs depending on the size of the jeans.  If using jeans the fabric needs to be cut since the machine is not big enough or heavy duty enough to cut through multiple layers of jeans fabric and seams)  You well also need material to cut out 12 - 5" squares of light weight fabric (I use cotton fabric scraps from my quilt making, but flannel or lace would work)  and about 1/3 yard of fusible pellon fleece.  I will provide instructions for making the table runner, and demonstrate how to make it.  We will NOT have time to sew on it at our meeting, but every one will know how to make it at home and have the cut out pieces.
results.name: Accuquilt - Demo by Loree

results.description:
We do our summer runs in the morning, because it works better for the school, and it's also cooler in the AMs. Plus, you get to start your day off right! :)

Welcome!


If you love to play basketball, but height is not your advantage, come out and play with people who aren't excessively tall! In the tradition of Spud Webb, anyone under 5'8", male or female, is welcome to join us on the court. We'll get some teams together and play some competitive, but relaxed bball-- and without any giant hands in our faces! :-p

We rent out the gym from 10:00am to 1:00pm. Please arrive at least 5-10 minutes early as the sooner everyone arrives, the sooner we can begin playing. Note that all games stop at 12:45pm as we have to be out of the gym by 1:00pm. (If you get there late, please only ring the bell once. It is very loud! And it takes us a few minutes to get downstairs.) The gym is on the 10th fl. & has adjoining bathrooms, lockers, and water fountains.

We'll hit up McSwiggans (393 2nd Avenue @ 23rd St) later! Don't forget:

* You must be no more than 5'8" to play!

* You must RSVP on the site in order to attend!

* You will be asked to sign a waiver for 2014 as we're not a litigious group. If you have any problems with the prepay, just shoot one of the organizers an email.

Here are the basic rules we follow for games: 1. Play by ones and twos to 11 - win by one point.

2. Make it - take it.

3. Backcourt if the ball hits the rim or backboard. Air balls are fair game to put right back up.

4. Jump balls/disputed calls will be determined by a three pointer since the laws of basketball physics are very clear that "the ball never lies."

5. Walls, half-court line, and ceiling are out of bounds. 6. Subs will enter the game no later than 6 points in (once one of the teams reaches 6 points). The sub will start the following game. Teams will regulate themselves but let's make sure everyone plays.

See you on the court! B-)

***NOTE***

In an effort for us to reduce overcrowding and to maintain a more accurate estimate of how many people to expect, please sign up online if you intend to play. There is a waiting list if all spots have been taken. We ask that you please just do not show up unannounced as you will kindly be asked to turned away. Also feel free to bring your own basketball for shoot-around. And don't forget to clip your nails prior to game day. We tried playing with Edward Scissorhands once - it didn't turn out so well.
results.name: Summer mornings pickup games

results.description:
Dog days of summer got you down? I've got just the cure for you!

Whether you like adrenaline-filled waterslides or just lounging pool side on a hot summer day, you’ll find thrills from mild to wild at Camelbeach, the biggest waterpark in Pennsylvania! With over thirty-seven rides, slides and attractions, dousing buckets, spraying water, hundreds of palm trees, cobblestone walkways, water rides, and beach sand, you're instantly transported to a waterpark oasis where adults can be kids again.

Ready? Set? Let's get wet!


What's the cost?

$39.99 per person for an all day park pass.

If you want to skip the wait in line, you can purchase your tickets online and print them HERE.

The important stuff ...

• Appropriate swimwear is required. Thong bottoms, cut off shorts, excessive buckles or ill-fitting suits are not allowed. No masks, swim fins, snorkels or shoes allowed either although you may wear aqua socks.

• No food, glass, or sharp objects are allowed to be brought into the park. You may carry in one unopened bottle of water. Storage lockers are available on site for rental.

• Life jackets are available to borrow on a first come, first served basis.

• Severe rain or similar un-favorable weather cancels the meetup.

• Check your email the evening before for last minute meetup updates.

How do I get there ...

One word--carpool. Or drive yourself. The water park is about 1.5 hours from midtown Manhattan so let's hitch the horses up to the chuck wagons and get a caravan going.

We will meet at the ticket windows @ 10:00AM.


If you plan to drive and are willing to carpool, please post in your RSVP where you are leaving from and how many people you can carry. If you'd like to carpool with someone please post your request and where you are located. Please don't wait to be offered a ride, BE PROACTIVE and contact any drivers directly to work out transportation details. As  courtesy, passengers should pick up tolls and gas.
results.name: Not So Urban Athletics: Camel Beach Waterpark Adventure

group.name: I wanted to do that...Just not alone!!

Two free trial sessions are available for newcomers; membership and playing fees are due for everyone else ($175 for full year, all included; membership year begins May 15). See (2015) Club and Facility Fees info for seasonal and per-session options. ACA Membership is required and due separately from club and facility fees (one-time ACA event membership is included for those in free trial sessions). Regulars: please confirm that your ACA membership is up to date or renew now. NYKP Members receive a discount! Newcomers can join ACA for 6 months at $15 for or for full year $30 (use PAC Individuals & Families options and select New York Kayak Polo). 

We may or may not set up a goal for this session, depending on numbers, but we can play the "football" version which is good fun and helps with your passing game.

In Williamsburg, we will visit the George Washington statue and pass Peter Lugar’s Restaurant on our way down Bedford Avenue to the Brooklyn Museum and Prospect Park.


Meet at 10:00AM at Delancey and Essex Sts. ( northwest corner of Delancey Street)---F train. Bring lunch, water, binoculars or a camera with an optical zoom lens. Heavy rain cancels. Call Friday evening until 9:00PM, if weather is an question.

results.description:
Join us for 12 amazing, uninterrupted hours of scrapbooking fun at a brand new hotel with comfortable seating.  There are no steps and luggage carts are available for convenience in moving your supplies. 


As always, we are working very hard to make this an enjoyable event for everyone.

Price - $40 which includes:

3 feet of cropping space.

Coffee and tea will be available all day, as well as candy.

Raffles and fabulous prizes!!!

Gifts! 

Fun games!

Tool Station:  Cricut and an assortment of cartridges, (please bring your own mats), and Cuttlebug machines will be available. 

We have the following Cricut Cartridges:  Accent Essentials, A Child's Year, All Mixed Up, Alphalicious, Animal Kingdom, Baseball, Base Camp, Beyond Birthdays, Blackletter, Camp Out, Celebrations, Christmas Cheer, Cursive 101, Cuttin' Up, Disney & Friends, Doodlecharms, Everyday Paper Dolls, Fabulous Finds, Forever Young, From My Kitchen, George, Going Places, Home Decor, Indie Art, Jasmine, Joys of the Season, Jubilee, Life's A Beach, Locker Talk, Love Struck, Lyrical Letters, Making The Grade, Meow, Mother's Day, My Community, My World, Old West, Opposites Attract, Pagoda, Paisley, Paper Dolls Dressup, Plantin Schoolbook, Printing Press, Printing Press 101, Pumpkin Carving, Simply Sweet, Songbird, Speaking of Fall, Sports Mania, Stand & Salute, Stamping, Stretch Your Imagination, Walk In My Garden, Wild Card, Winter Woodland, Wedding.

If you would like a specific one to be available at the crop, please message us and we will be sure to have it on hand for you. 

Vendors Pending!!! 

We are also working on getting a licensed chiropractor to do massage therapy!  Please indicate your interest if you would like a massage as that will decide his attendance. 

Space is limited to 19 spots which are on a first come, first served basis and are not guaranteed unless you have paid. Checks and cash will not be accepted.  Non-refundable fee required at time of RSVP.

Tell us who you would like to sit with and we will do our best to accommodate everyone's request.

The hotel has various sandwiches, wraps, snacks and beverages available for sale but you may also order in from local area restaurants which will deliver.  You may bring your own food as there is a microwave for your use.  Please note, however, no refrigeration available. 

Bring your scrap-maBob drink holder.

Remember extension cords if you require electricity for your devices. 

On-site valet parking available for a reduced rate.

For questions or comments, please email Ora at [masked] or Serene at [masked].

We hope to see you there!
results.name: July Crop

results.description:
Jim Wood's ~ "Touching the Wild Edges" ~ Lessons in Celtic Shamanism ~ Full Day Intensive


Our ancestors lived in a wild, dangerous and unpredictable world. To survive involved an innate understanding that the Earth is an intelligent, living being and complex system - of which humans are only a small part.  Over millennia, we have lost this understanding and isolated ourselves from the lessons of the Earth.  To regain this lost knowledge we must once again “touch the Wild Edges” and become comfortable with uncertainty and Chaos while living in order.


Join us for a journey of Self-Discovery using ancient Irish Fomorian stories to learn:

~Celtic Shamanism through a Celtic/Druidic view of the World 

~Techniques on how to remain balanced and whole

~How to ‘Dance with the Dark’ w/out being overwhelmed or seduced by it

~How to retain an interconnectedness and interdependence with all living things

~And much more 


Jim Wood is a graduate of the Foundation for Shamanic Studies' training programs in numerous Shamanism and Shamanic Healing courses as well as a graduate of Sandra Ingerman's Shamanic Teacher Training. He has studied Celtic Shamanism extensively with Tom Cowan and co-facilitates Shamanic Workshops and Gatherings with Tom. He is a Trained Shamanic Practitioner and Shamanic Counselor and an Ordained Druid in the Fellowship of Druids of the Later Age (FoDLA). He is also a student and dabbler in Herbalism and Alchemy.


Jim has a private Shamanic healing practice in New York’s Hudson Valley consisting of all aspects of Shamanic Healing including Soul Retrieval, Extraction, Depossession, Power Animal Retrieval and Psycho-pomp work and is the founder of the FoDLA Grove of the Greenwood.  Jim also teaches Shamanic Journeying, Celtic Shamanism and Soul Retrieval workshops and facilitates several Shamanic Drumming Circles.  He can be reached via

www.CelticWisdom.com

RSVP here: https://www.paypal.com/us/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_flow&SESSION=Z6eLFDOa8mU7UUUT23jsQJIJKJC1DkDCpd7k7GSzKDTqdzIZ2Oi4wdwIv94&dispatch=5885d80a13c0db1f8e263663d3faee8de6030e9239419d79c3f52f70a3ed57ec


More Info contact Cristina Maria via email address:

Brunch – 10:45 am

What to expect: a seriously fun group of runners who definitely do not take running too seriously . We will meet, chat, RUN, stretch, chat, EAT BREAKFAST and then leave. It’s that easy. First we run, then we eat!

results.description:
This tour costs $10.00 with all proceeds to the Broadway Mall Association (BMA), a non-profit organization that has worked to beautify and maintain the malls for 30 years.  The malls extend from Lincoln Center to  168th Street.  Read more here:  www.broadwaymall.org.

Tour covers the area from 155th Street to 168th Street both East and West of Broadway in Lower Washington Heights. The Audubon Terrace area was once the home of painter and naturalist John James Audubon and now is occupied by Manhattan’s only active cemetery (Trinity Church Cemetery). You will be surprised to learn of some of the people buried here. We'll also visit the magnificent Church of the Intercession and Hispanic Society of America, one of New York’s most unique free museums with an extraordinary collection of art and artifacts from Spain, Portugal and Latin America.  Further uptown we’ll also visit the delightful Morris Jumel Mansion, Manhattan’s oldest house built in 1765 which once served as General George Washington’s headquarters in 1776 and where in 1790 as President he dined with members of his cabinet:  Thomas Jefferson, John Adams and Alexander Hamilton.  You will scarcely believe that you are in Manhattan while strolling these quiet streets that surround the mansion.  Rounding out the tour will be a stop at the Malcolm X Memorial and for baseball fans we will traverse the site where the Yankees began as the New York Highlanders.  Optional brunch/ lunch after the tour at Coogan’s Restaurant on Broadway.

Note:  In addition the Jumel Mansion has a modest admission admission charge: of $3 - $5 dollars


Meeting Place: Small triangle park (Ilka Tanya Pagan Park), located on the Westside of Broadway near the 157th Street.  The #1 subway gets you right there. Note you can also take the A train to 168th Street either walk, ride Broadway bus or take the #1 downtown one stop.
results.how_to_find_us: Take the #1 subway to 157th Street.  The little park is right there on the downtown side of Broadway.
results.name: Exploring Unknown Manhattan:  The Audubon and Jumel Terrace Historic Districts.

results.description:
Registration on the L.L. Bean website is required to attend this event. Visit www.llbean.com/RidgeHill to reserve your spot.

90 minute classes begin at 10:00AM and 1PM both Saturday and Sunday

Our Kayaking Discovery Course is a great way to learn the basic paddling techniques and safety skills of this popular sport. Exploring nature in a kayak is a healthy and fun way to enjoy the outdoors. Our course begins with a brief introduction and safety talk from our friendly paddling instructors, who will share their knowledge gained from years of kayaking. They'll outfit you with a personal flotation device (PFD), kayak and paddling equipment, giving you insight on the best ways to set up your boat. Then, you'll receive instruction on a variety of paddling techniques.

After you feel comfortable on the water, you'll set out in a kayak on a guided, interpretive tour with your group. You'll experience the freedom of skimming across the water, learning about the ecosystem and history of the area.

All necessary paddling equipment is provided.
results.name: Kayaking Discovery Course Every Saturday and Sunday Only $25

Note: When you RSVP we will send you a telephone number you can call/text in case you have any trouble finding us.

What people are saying:

Achelle - #ThriveInThePark is the workout I look forward to all week! Not only do I get an incredible full body workout, but it's a fun and encouraging group to be apart of!

Devon - #ThriveInThePark is the best way to sweat out last night's wine.

Andie - #ThriveInThePark I never thought I would enjoy waking up early on a Saturday, but now I look forward to it, fun workouts with friends that keep you motivated to push yourself!

Dani - #ThriveInThePark I Love everything about it! Such a positive way to bring community together for some weekend activity. The guys/girls that lead the workout and stretches bring such great energy to the group, we basically laugh the whole time - until the lunges and burpees come along, no one laughs at those.

Thrive in the Park was created by a group of friends with a common interest in fitness, clean food, and having a great time.

Our goal is to get in the best shape while in the company of great people.

http://www.ThriveInThePark.com

We can't wait to see you!

results.description:
Compete (or casually partake) in Singles Tennis to support Kings County Tennis League's youth programming! Registration is open until July 8 at midnight. Sign up and submit payment at KCTL.eventsmart.com. 

Cost of Entry
Entry for this flexible tennis tournament is available to the public. The cost for current KCTL volunteers & staff is $10. For all other players, the cost is $20.

When & Where
The KCTL Open will take place over the course of approximately one month (June 27 through July 30). Participants will have one week to play assigned matches at their own convenience and at locations of their choice.

Why Play?
All tournament proceeds will benefit the growth and development of Kings County Tennis League, a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization that uses tennis as an instrument to mentor underserved children in Bed-Stuy, Brooklyn. (Learn more at <a>www.kingscountytennisleague.org)</a>

Divisions
The KCTL Open is segmented into three divisions:
• Men's Competitive
• Women's Competitive
• Co-Ed Recreational

Men's & Women's Competitive are single-elimination tournaments for players rated 4.0 and above; Co-Ed Recreational is a non-elimination round-robin for players rated 3.5 and below. 

Rules & Registration
For a detailed list of tournament rules and to sign up, visit KCTL.eventsmart.com.
results.name: 2nd Annual KCTL Open Tennis Tournament (Register @ KCTL.eventsmart.com)

Updated April 18th, 2015

This is one of three sites/listserves that promotes weekly games that have been going on for many many years. Stall counts are used on occasion, cleats are optional, boundaries are flexible, and all skill levels are welcome!

There are two ways to stay in touch outside of Meetup.com:

- Follow us on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/nycultimate
- Like us on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/nycultimate

SPRING/SUMMER (Mar - Aug)

As the city warms up we play four times a week. We use Riverside Park on Tuesdays/Thursdays and Morningside Park for the weekend games.

There are four days that we play:

- Saturdays at 10am, Morningside Park (110th and Manhattan Ave) 
- Sundays at 12pm, Morningside Park (110th and Manhattan Ave) 
- Tuesdays at 6pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End - Where we can!) 
- Thursdays at 6pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End - Where we can!)

Damien 
[masked]


MORNINGSIDE DETAILS

The Morningside location is at the corner of 110th Street and Manhattan Avenue. The best way to get there is to take the B or C local to 110th Street. You can also take the 1 train to 110th street at Broadway and then walk East. We will play at the South end of the baseball field parallel to 110th street so that we're not in the way of the baseball games. Riverside will be our backup if for some reason we need to change locations.
results.why: It's a great way to start your Saturday!
results.name: Saturday Ultimate @ 10AM - Morningside Park

results.description:
Whether you are visiting our beautiful city, coming from a lesson, or just have the day off...come on out and hit with us! We are a group of tennis enthusiast of 2.5 to 4.0 levels that have the fundamental parts of the game down and like to hit against different styles of play.


WHY PLAY HERE?

Well, first of all it is a nice serene location (i.e. no basketball courts, grandstands, or any other type of distraction). Secondly, consider the cost options to play else elsewhere in-and-around the city...


1) unless you have endless tennis competitors on your roll-a-dex, you'll need a web-based database/system to find people. Most of these tennis databases/systems charge in different ways. Fact, Meetup charges me a premium every month because of the member pool size and this has to be  prepaid just to keep the group alive.

2) if you play elsewhere, you will need a permit which will currently cost you $15 for a single day (or $200 for a yearly). To be more specific, these two options really only entitle you to one hour of singles play (vs. 2 hours here), meaning your partner will also need a permit.

3) new balls are provided at the beginning of each day. Typical extra-duty balls run about $3 per can off-the-shelf, so if you are an avid player...you'll save time and money running around picking-up tennis balls.

4) if someone were to break a string, or you just want to try a different racquet for an evaluation (i.e. lighter weight, bigger head, tighter strings, etc), racquets are available at no addition cost.

5) seasonally "clean" courts. Throughout the year tennis courts pile up with blowing leaves, pollen, acorns, etc. I get here early every session to ensure the courts are clean. I do this with a battery-powered blower and if any body knows anything about batteries...its that they don't last! Each time I have to replace one (which only does one court), it cost me nearly $100 for each.

6) portions of fee here actually go repairing the courts and/or nets. Case-and-point the cement required to fill cracks which was recently done by myself.

7) there are port-a-potty's and 2 drinking fountains available for all to use

8) no dress code required like some places...but proper edict is appreciated


9) based on the talent that signup, I may ask people to move around to establish a competitive session for all those involved


Hopefully this addresses all those questions like: is it free or why does it cost.

WAYS TO RSVP...

Within Meetup, just click RSVP for the time slot that works best with your schedule and be resposible to attend. You can prepay (eliminating the need to remember to carry cash) a number of ways:

Reserve via PayPal ([masked]) vs. cash and select friends (not service) to avoid additional PayPal fees

OR

1. Create an account at MindBodyOnline scheduling software:

https://clients.mindbodyonline.com/classic/home?studioid=152916


2. Decide which package you want to purchase:

1 session = $25; Use Promo Code = T15TS1 

3 sessions @ $20 = $60; Use Promo Code = T15TS3 

6 sessions @ $17 = $102; Use Promo Code = T15TS6 

10 sessions @ $15 = $150; Use Promo Code = T15TS10

3. Go to the Online Store and before Checking Out; APPLY the Promo code of your choice to receive discounted pricing.  

4. Go to the Day and Time of your choice to RSVP your attendance

WEATHER

Weather is always an unpredictable thing but remember, just because a forecast says 30% chance of showers...that also means 70% chance of no showers. Also with the 30% it may be in your area, but not where the courts are. Lastly, if it does sprinkle...we have the necessary equipment to dry them.

http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc

DIRECTIONS

We are directly south of the George Washington Bridge right on the Hudson River. Best ways to get there are A train, M4 or M98 bus, biking along the river or driving and parking on Riverside Drive behind the Presbyterian hospital (being the less favorite).

http://www.google.com/maps/@40.8494798,-73.9430776,16z?hl=en

(walking via 181 street subway stop)

1. Take A Train to 181st Street Station (sit in the back of the train).

2. Walk West on 181st Street which turns into Plaza Lafayette.

3. Make a Right, on Riverside Drive to the light green Pedestrian Crossover Bridge.

4. Cross the pedestrian bridge and follow the ramp down proceeding toward the GW Bridge which zigzags (crossing over the railroad tracks), and down the hill.

5. Arrive at the courts on your left.

Please plan an additional 15 minutes for weekend subway schedule delays and note its takes an additional 15 minutes to walk from 181st Street Station to the courts, so please arrive before scheduled slot so everyone can start on time.

<a href="http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc"></a>

results.description:
As a Nature Therapy Guide, I have learned to have an even deeper connection to Nature.  I didn't think that was possible. After all, I grew up in rural Vermont and already loved the outdoors.  I learned through the practice of Shinrin-Yoku and I'd love to show you what it's all about.  If you aren't familiar, please check out this recent article on the practice and its benefits.  The author also speaks of the Association where I got my training.

The walk will be in a beautiful part of the park called the Loch: a forested area with towering oaks with a stream and cascading waterfall.  I'll invite you to partake in a series of sensory activities along the way and we'll all share in that experience together.  Returning Nature Connectors welcome!  Every walk is different and unique.

There is a $10 suggested donation that, if you are pleased and willing, you can give me at the end of the walk.  

There is a limit of 12 people on this one so when you sign up you're in!  Please be on time as I power down my device at the top of the meetup.  I can't accommodate folks who want to join in midway through as it's best if we are all present from the top.  Here is my cell [masked]) if you're lost or running late- or message me here if you have any questions.

I'll see you all soon!  Until then try to spend some quality time (2-3 hours) with nature every week.  It can be a challenge here in the city but you can do it- Heck, you probably already are:)  

DUNCAN
results.how_to_find_us: I'll be standing right at the entrance to the park:)
results.name: Deepen your Connection to Nature

results.description:
IC Brief

You are going about your daily business when you are approached by a small man in colorful robes, he walks up to you and asks your name, he nods at you as if to confirm you are indeed you are the person he is looking for, he swiftly pulls out a piece of parchment from his bag and presents it to you it reads:

University of Miracles  

Student Name: Hubert Matterson

Disciplines: Air + Water

In accordance to the rules and regulations of the Twilight Tower, the bearer of this document is a licensed magic user and as such is permitted to freely use the arcane arts in within the laws of the land

He gives you time to read over his document before he begins to speak

“The headmistress Cadiretirem has requested your presence at the University of Miracles, she has informed me that she requires you to travel to Azmar immediately and that more information will be provided upon arrival”

Usual bit here everyone, meet at 10am try and be in kit and ready by 10.30am. We will meet outside of the bathrooms at the Seaman Ave-Isham St entrance to Inwood Hill Park. For new players the easiest way to get to the meet up location is to take the A train to the 207th street stop, exit the station at Isham street and it is a 2 minute walk from there.

Bring water we will be running around in the heat all day

results.description:
***************************************************

Due to rain on 6/27-28, this event has been rescheduled for 7/11-12

***************************************************


I propose an overnight on the Suffern-Bear Mountain trail which is totally accessible via public transportation from NYC. Here is the basic mileage and trip outline:

Day 1:

Port Authority Shortline Bus #781 8:45 AM arriving at Bear Mountain 10:15

S-BM trail head to Big Hill Shelter: 12.25 miles

Day 2:

Big Hill Shelter to Trail End: 11.15 miles

Suffern Train Station is .4 miles from Trail End, and the bus stop is on the way to the train.

Suffern train leaves for Penn Station every hour on the 8s (exception is 4:32). Bus leaves at 2:38, 4:00, 5:00 for Port Authority.

****I am NOT a wilderness expert or an official guide. You need to be self sufficient to join this hike. There will be no sweep group and we will move at our own paces. I'm the kind of hiker that likes to get to the destination and then hang/relax as opposed to stopping constantly along the way. Feel free to do the mileage as you like and I'll see you at camp if we're not close together on the trail.

Who: Intermediate backpackers. We'll be doing 11+ miles a day so be fit and ready to put in some mileage. Backpacking is 3X harder than day hiking.

Gear (this is NOT an all encompassing list):
Tent (or other appropriate shelter - the Lean to could be full), hiking boots, backpack, sleeping bag, sleeping pad, appropriate clothing for day and night, rain/wind gear, headlamp, food dish and utensil (1 breakfast, 2 lunches and 1 dinner), snacks, stove/fuel/pot, water filters/chemical treatment, insect repellent, sunscreen, 1st aid kit, water bladders/nalgene bottles, start with 3L+ of water, bear bag and rope.

You MUST also bring both PAPER Harriman Maps 118/119. Do not solely rely on the Avenza APP for this.

***I will post more info if I think of anything else important. This is my first time organizing an event, so bear with me :)

***If the weather forecast the day or two before promises downpours, record heat or some other craziness, I will cancel.
results.name: Suffern-Bear Mountain Trail Backpack (accessible by Public Transit)

results.description:
Join us on Saturday, July 11, 2015 at 10:15 a.m. to hear Howard Bloom speak on the topic America Needs A Vision Implant. He will speak for 45 minutes to be followed by 45 minutes of Q & A. The event will take place in the Library of the Queens Pride House located at[masked]th Avenue, Suite 206, Jackson Heights, New York 11372.

ADMISSION FEE: $3.00 for Queens LP Members; $5.00 for Non-Members 

If you are driving, arrive early to look for free street parking. There are also many 2-hourMuni-Meter spots and a nearby parking lot. 

If you are coming by subway, use the IRT "7" Flushing Line and exit at 74th Street/Broadway. You can also use the IND "E", "F" or "R" Queens Blvd. Lines and exit at the Jackson Heights/Roosevelt Avenue stop.

============================== Howard Bloom has been called "next in a lineage of seminal thinkers that includes Newton, Darwin, Einstein, [and] Freud," by Britain's Channel4 TV, "the next Stephen Hawking" by Gear Magazine, and "The Buckminster Fuller and Arthur C. Clarke of the new millennium" by Buckminster Fuller's archivist. Bloom is the author of six books: The Lucifer Principle: A Scientific Expedition Into the Forces of History ("mesmerizing"-The Washington Post), Global Brain: The Evolution of Mass Mind from the Big Bang to the 21st Century ("reassuring and sobering"-The New Yorker), The Genius of the Beast: A Radical Re-Vision of Capitalism ("Impressive, stimulating, and tremendously enjoyable." James Fallows, National Correspondent, The Atlantic), The God Problem: How A Godless Cosmos Creates ("Bloom's argument will rock your world." Barbara Ehrenreich), How I Accidentally Started the Sixties (“Wow! Whew! Wild! Wonderful!” Timothy Leary), and The Mohammed Code (“a terrifying book…the best book I’ve read on Islam,” David Swindle, PJ Media).

Bloom’s second book, Global Brain, was the subject of an Office of the Secretary of Defense symposium in 2010, with participants from the State Department, the Energy Department, DARPA, IBM, and MIT. Bloom is founder and head of the Space Development Steering Committee, a group that includes astronauts Buzz Aldrin, Edgar Mitchell (the sixth man on the moon), and members from the National Science Foundation, NASA, and the National Space Society. He has debated one-one-one with senior officials from Egypt's Moslem Brotherhood and Gaza's Hamas on Iran's global Arab-language Alalam TV News Network. He has also dissected headline issues over forty times on Saudi Arabia's KSA2-TV, Ekhbariya TV, Economics TV, and on Iran's global English language Press-TV. Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum, Dubai’s ruler, who doubles as the Prime Minister of the United Arab Emirates, has named a racehorse after one of Bloom’s books. Bloom has probed the untold story of the Syrian Civil War with Nancy Kissinger. He is currently working with Caltech’s Keck Institute for Space Studies on two projects: the first parallel-processing planetary mission (a mission to Mars); and an energy infrastructure for the solar system.

Bloom’s area of expertise is mass behavior, from the mass behavior of quarks to the mass behavior of human beings. He has lectured at Yale, Stanford, and Columbia University's Department of Neuroscience. He has published on theoretical physics, cosmology, and evolutionary biology. His scientific work has appeared in: arxiv.org, the leading pre-print site in advanced theoretical physics and math; PhysicaPlus; Across Species Comparisons and Psychopathology; New Ideas in Psychology; The Journal of Space Philosophy; and in the book series: Research in Biopolitics. He lectured an international conference of quantum physicists in Moscow—Quantum Informatics 2006—on why everything we know about quantum physics is wrong, and the concepts Bloom introduced were later used in a book proposing a new approach to quantum physics, Constructive Physics, by Moscow University’s Yuri Ozhigov.

In addition, Bloom’s writing has appeared in The Washington Post, The Wall Street Journal, Wired, Knight-Ridder Financial News Service, the Village Voice, Cosmopolitan Magazine, and the Scientific American’sscientificamerican.com. Bloom has also appeared one hundred and eleven times for up to five hours on 500 radio stations on the highest-rated overnight talk radio show in North America, Clear Channel’s Coast to Coast AM, discussing everything from the biome in the gut and the evolution of the stars to the rise of the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS).

Bloom has founded three international scientific groups: the Group Selection Squad (1995), which gained acceptance for the concept of group selection in evolutionary biology; The International Paleopsychology Project (1997), which created a new multi-disciplinary synthesis between cosmology, paleontology, evolutionary biology, and history; and The Space Development Steering Committee (2007).

Bloom recovered from fifteen years bedbound with Chronic Fatigue Syndrome in 2003, and since then has done stints as a visiting scholar in the Graduate School of Psychology at NYU and as a core faculty member at the Graduate Institute in Meriden, Connecticut. He’s been flown to Moscow, Amsterdam, Paris, Seoul, Kuala Lumpur, Kobe, and Chengdu, China to lecture. He’s also lectured at American locations from Nellis Air Force Base and the Eisenhower Center for Space and Defense Studies to Yale University. He is currently on both the board and the board of governors of the National Space Society.

Topping it all off, Bloom's computer houses a not-so-secret and not-at-all humble 60-year project, his 8,370-chapter-long Grand Unified Theory of Everything in the Universe Including the Human Soul. Pavel Kurakin of the Keldysh Institute of Applied Mathematics of the Russian Academy of Sciences says that, "Bloom has created a new Scientific Paradigm. He explains in vast and compelling terms why we should forget all we know in complicated modern math and should start from the very beginning. Bloom's Grand Unified Theory opens a window into entire systems we don't yet know and/or see, new collectivities that live, love, battle, win and lose each day of our gray lives. I never imagined that a new system of thought could produce so much light."


----------------------
Howard Bloom
Howardbloom.net
Author of: The Lucifer Principle: A Scientific Expedition Into the Forces of History ("mesmerizing"-The Washington Post), 
Global Brain: The Evolution of Mass Mind From The Big Bang to the 21st Century ("reassuring and sobering"-The New Yorker),

The Mohammed Code (“A terrifying book…the best book I’ve read on Islam.” David Swindle, PJ Media).

Board Member and Member Of Board Of Governors, National Space Society. Founding Board Member: Epic of Evolution Society. Founding Board Member, The Darwin Project. results.description:
Join us on Saturday, July 11, 2015 at 10:15 a.m. to hear Howard Bloom speak on the topic America Needs A Vision Implant. He will speak for 45 minutes to be followed by 45 minutes of Q & A. The event will take place in the Library of the Queens Pride House located at[masked]th Avenue, Suite 206, Jackson Heights, New York 11372.

ADMISSION FEE: $5.00 

If you are driving, arrive early to look for free street parking. There are also many 2-hourMuni-Meter spots and a nearby parking lot. 

If you are coming by subway, use the IRT "7" Flushing Line and exit at 74th Street/Broadway. You can also use the IND "E", "F" or "R" Queens Blvd. Lines and exit at the Jackson Heights/Roosevelt Avenue stop.

============================== Howard Bloom has been called "next in a lineage of seminal thinkers that includes Newton, Darwin, Einstein, [and] Freud," by Britain's Channel4 TV, "the next Stephen Hawking" by Gear Magazine, and "The Buckminster Fuller and Arthur C. Clarke of the new millennium" by Buckminster Fuller's archivist. Bloom is the author of six books: The Lucifer Principle: A Scientific Expedition Into the Forces of History ("mesmerizing"-The Washington Post), Global Brain: The Evolution of Mass Mind from the Big Bang to the 21st Century ("reassuring and sobering"-The New Yorker), The Genius of the Beast: A Radical Re-Vision of Capitalism ("Impressive, stimulating, and tremendously enjoyable." James Fallows, National Correspondent, The Atlantic), The God Problem: How A Godless Cosmos Creates ("Bloom's argument will rock your world." Barbara Ehrenreich), How I Accidentally Started the Sixties (“Wow! Whew! Wild! Wonderful!” Timothy Leary), and The Mohammed Code (“a terrifying book…the best book I’ve read on Islam,” David Swindle, PJ Media).

Bloom’s second book, Global Brain, was the subject of an Office of the Secretary of Defense symposium in 2010, with participants from the State Department, the Energy Department, DARPA, IBM, and MIT. Bloom is founder and head of the Space Development Steering Committee, a group that includes astronauts Buzz Aldrin, Edgar Mitchell (the sixth man on the moon), and members from the National Science Foundation, NASA, and the National Space Society. He has debated one-one-one with senior officials from Egypt's Moslem Brotherhood and Gaza's Hamas on Iran's global Arab-language Alalam TV News Network. He has also dissected headline issues over forty times on Saudi Arabia's KSA2-TV, Ekhbariya TV, Economics TV, and on Iran's global English language Press-TV. Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum, Dubai’s ruler, who doubles as the Prime Minister of the United Arab Emirates, has named a racehorse after one of Bloom’s books. Bloom has probed the untold story of the Syrian Civil War with Nancy Kissinger. He is currently working with Caltech’s Keck Institute for Space Studies on two projects: the first parallel-processing planetary mission (a mission to Mars); and an energy infrastructure for the solar system.

Bloom’s area of expertise is mass behavior, from the mass behavior of quarks to the mass behavior of human beings. He has lectured at Yale, Stanford, and Columbia University's Department of Neuroscience. He has published on theoretical physics, cosmology, and evolutionary biology. His scientific work has appeared in: arxiv.org, the leading pre-print site in advanced theoretical physics and math; PhysicaPlus; Across Species Comparisons and Psychopathology; New Ideas in Psychology; The Journal of Space Philosophy; and in the book series: Research in Biopolitics. He lectured an international conference of quantum physicists in Moscow—Quantum Informatics 2006—on why everything we know about quantum physics is wrong, and the concepts Bloom introduced were later used in a book proposing a new approach to quantum physics, Constructive Physics, by Moscow University’s Yuri Ozhigov.

In addition, Bloom’s writing has appeared in The Washington Post, The Wall Street Journal, Wired, Knight-Ridder Financial News Service, the Village Voice, Cosmopolitan Magazine, and the Scientific American’sscientificamerican.com. Bloom has also appeared one hundred and eleven times for up to five hours on 500 radio stations on the highest-rated overnight talk radio show in North America, Clear Channel’s Coast to Coast AM, discussing everything from the biome in the gut and the evolution of the stars to the rise of the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS).

Bloom has founded three international scientific groups: the Group Selection Squad (1995), which gained acceptance for the concept of group selection in evolutionary biology; The International Paleopsychology Project (1997), which created a new multi-disciplinary synthesis between cosmology, paleontology, evolutionary biology, and history; and The Space Development Steering Committee (2007).

Bloom recovered from fifteen years bedbound with Chronic Fatigue Syndrome in 2003, and since then has done stints as a visiting scholar in the Graduate School of Psychology at NYU and as a core faculty member at the Graduate Institute in Meriden, Connecticut. He’s been flown to Moscow, Amsterdam, Paris, Seoul, Kuala Lumpur, Kobe, and Chengdu, China to lecture. He’s also lectured at American locations from Nellis Air Force Base and the Eisenhower Center for Space and Defense Studies to Yale University. He is currently on both the board and the board of governors of the National Space Society.

Bloom's Grand Unified Theory opens a window into entire systems we don't yet know and/or see, new collectivities that live, love, battle, win and lose each day of our gray lives. I never imagined that a new system of thought could produce so much light."

Every time we have a fencing meetup in the park, we meet new people.  Some of them are meetup members who couldn't make meetups at other times, others are just people in the park.  But they're all fun.

Cancellations are much more likely in the summer!  A meetup can be canceled because the ground is too wet, rain is predicted, high heat & humidity are predicted, or just because there aren't enough people committed to being there.  PLEASE RSVP, and come if you say you will. I will post cancellations here by 9am on the day.


To find us, enter the park via the entrance opposite the Ethical Culture School (The Ethical Culture School is on the west side of Central Park West) at 63rd and Central Park West.  The "Backup Fencing Spot" is on your right, just inside the entrance to the park.  Soccer kids have been grabbing our "Where We Fence" location pretty steadily, but to find it, follow the paved path in a large arc to your left, (It starts off heading SE and curves around to NW).  The "Where We Fence" location is on the hard packed dirt under the trees. 


We have a very limited amount of equipment to lend. We're willing to share, but if you have your own equipment, please bring it.

It's also a good idea to bring water!

A more detailed map of where we fence in Central Park is here:

https://maps.google.com/maps/ms?msid=212152258049056562883.0004db7dc1516e1da7244&msa=0&ie=UTF8&t=m&z=17&vpsrc=0

I look forward to fencing you!

- Mike

results.description:
This series runs all day, but you are welcome to drop in when you like.  If you would like to see all 5 Cremasters but cannot do it in one day, know that there will be multiple showings of the series.

The CREMASTER cycle, created and produced by Matthew Barney, is a series of five visually extravagant films made out of sequence (CREMASTER 4 began the cycle, followed by CREMASTER 1, 5, 2, and finally, CREMASTER 3) but presented here in the order of their creation. The title of the cycle refers to the muscle that raises and lowers the male reproductive system according to external stimuli such as temperature or fear. Taken in sequential order, the films correlate to the height of the gonads during the embryonic process of sexual differentiation, with CREMASTER 1 representing the most “ascended” state, and CREMASTER 5 the most “descended.”

As the cycle evolved over eight years (1994–2002), this biological model was joined by other paradigms such as history, autobiography and mythology that have added to Barney’s fantastical narrative constructs. The resulting cosmology is both beautiful and complex, with densely layered and interconnected symbols and images.

The films are screened here in chronological order of their production to reveal the development of Barney’s relationship to the material and of his creative process.

Schedule
10:30 am, CREMASTER 4 (1994), 41 min.
11:15 am, CREMASTER 1 (1995), 42 min.
12:15 pm, CREMASTER 5 (1997), 55 min.
2:45 pm, CREMASTER 2 (1999), 80 min.
4:30 pm, CREMASTER 3 (2002), 178 min.

Free with museum admission.

For detailed info on the series follow these links
http://www.guggenheim.org/new-york/calendar-and-events/2015/06/06/the-cremaster-cycle/4787
http://www.cremaster.net/

For admission hours and location follow this link http://www.guggenheim.org/new-york/visit
results.name: THE CREMASTER CYCLE at the Guggenheim

results.description:
Come for an introduction to Tai Chi and Alexander Technique!

This is the 1st class in a 4 class series.  The first class is $5. The remaining 3 classes are  $42 (for the whole series)  

In this 4-class series, participants will learn the beginning of the Wu-Style Tai Chi form, a 108 sequence of movements. In addition, proper alignment within the form will be learned using the Alexander Technique.  Tai Chi is an excellent way to practice Alexander Technique principles and to learn how to move with ease, relieve tension and to move more gracefully.

Wu Style Tai Chi: is a Chinese martial arts system that uses slow, meditative, deliberate movements to learn a fighting system and healthy body posture. In particular, the Wu System uses a shorter stance to create more power and thrust from the practitioner's base.  Benefits include, pain relief, grace, joint health and stress-relief. 

Form: http://youtu.be/Wpi8WzumE8g

Push-hands: http://youtu.be/TL2s07_oQZA

Alexander Technique: is a system of learning how to move more efficiently. The technique supports self-sufficiency, awareness, ease of movement, and healthy posture. 

First class: Saturday 10:30am, 7/11

Following classes: Saturdays, 10:30-11:30am: 7/18, 7/25, 8/22

RSVP required. 

--

Warmly,

Kai Kleinbard

executive functions coach and Alexander Technique teacher

thebodyliterate.com


The bodyLITERATE is dedicated to supporting executive functions in youth through integrating our coaching/tutoring services with the Alexander Technique. We engender efficient, embodied and joyful learning and academic success in young learners and guide parents to create effective learning systems at home. In addition, we run a research lab through the  bodyLITERATE Incubator, providing opportunities to explore creativity and play within the framework of effective learning.

results.description:
Studio Series #2

Easing the Overwhelm, Reducing Worry, Managing Anxiety

Nearly 90% of the time, the brain and body don’t know the difference between what we think we’re experiencing versus what we’re actually experiencing. That’s how our worrying can cause physical symptoms as if we were in a threatening environment, but also how guided imagery can cause physical symptoms of relaxation as if we were lounging beachside in Bali.

Learn how to harness power of your mind and imagination to give your mind a rest. When the mind is experiencing relaxation, pleasure, or stillness - even for just 10 minutes - the body responds accordingly. 

At this Meetup, we'll connect and talk about the topic via informal group discussion, then experience a full Guided Imagery, followed by Q&A, connecting with other like-minded women, warm tea, and light refreshments (aka chocolate.)

What to expect:

All of Enodia Center’s sessions, Studio Series, and community events are designed to be realistic for every woman. You don’t have to alter your beliefs, lifestyle, or wardrobe to experience all the benefits of our Studio Series. Therefore, this is a totally "come as you are" Meetup. The only request we have is that you remove your shoes, so comfy socks are always a plus!  

As always, don't hesitate to contact me at [masked] with any questions. Looking forward to connecting with you!



**Please note, all payments must be received at least 2 days prior to the event, otherwise your space will be released to another Meetup member. Don't hesitate to contact me with any questions about this. Thank you for your cooperation, and we look forward to seeing you there!**

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers.

6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
**INDOOR, FUTSAL OR SNEAKERS**  

                               NO CLEATS or PLASTIC STUDS!

         NON-COMPETITIVE CO-ED PICKUP SOCCER GAMES 

                                      @ RIVERSIDE Park!

                             See our page on Facebook!:

                        ManhattanInternationalCoedSoccer

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RQxq4zYJDFg

DESCRIPTION:

Our games are for all levels and people that prefer to play a non-competitive game of soccer, break a sweat while exercising running up and down the field with the ball and all this happening in a very laid-back and non-judgmental environment. Please, arrive 10 minutes before the game so we can get the teams set up.

We'll play 3 simultaneous games of 8 on 8, with goals. There will be 6 teams on the field and we will play three games, 30 minutes/game. Every 30 minutes we will have a short break and teams will switch to play against different team. Please check your email or our meetup message board on friday night or before 12.00pm on Saturday to see what team you are on. This will save us a lot of time on the field.

RULES OF THE GAME:

First and most important rule of the game is to have fun and enjoy the time on the field! Rough play and offensive language will absolutely not be tolerated!!! In plain words, no slide tackling, no pushing and no telling off.

No power shots allowed. No power shots means; you can shoot the ball but not as hard as you can. This doesn't mean that you can not take the shot at all. Kicking the ball or taking the shot on the goal, is of course allowed.

If you don't sign up for the game, do not show up.

If you are late for the game, you must wait until the game in progress is over to join your team.

Those that don't comply with these rules, will kindly be asked to leave the field so others can enjoy the game and maybe a two game ban.

Any other questions regarding the rules of the game or anything else, should be directed to the organizer directly or to the assistant organizer/s!!!

Location:

Riverside Park at West 107 & 108 Street

Take the 1 RED Line Train to Cathedral Pkwy an walk two blocks down, to 108th Street and Riverside Dr.

The field is down the lower level near the river. You can easly access the field from 108th Street. Remember, the field is not visable from the street level, you have to walk down the stairs from Riverside Dr & 108th Street. and you will see the newly renovated fanced-in soccer field next to the river.

Call me if you can’t find the field - [masked] Manny S.


What to bring with you:

A pair of sneakers, indoor or turf shoes, shin guards (recommended) and lots of water. There is a water fountain next to the park if you need extra water.

Fee:

You will be asked to pay $9.25 when you RSVP. This $9.25 is used to pay for, facilities permits, meetup fees, Amazon fees, goals, cones, soccer balls etc.

Refunds & Weather Policy:

Refunds will be issued if the RSVP is changed by Wednesday before 12.00PM or if the game is cancelled. The game can be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe like heavy rain, snow or thunder.

After the game we'll head to a local bar for brunch and a Pint or Two.

results.description:
Do something GREAT this Summer!!


Take Acoustic Guitar Lessons in Central Park
Free Group Lessons Saturdays, May 16th to October 17.


You will learn to read notes, chords and play songs you know and love.  You will have the opportunity to learn:


• Basic info about the guitar
• To read and play chords
• To read and play Rhythm
• Techniques for using the pick
• How play finger style.
• What you learn can be applied to Rock, Blues, Folk, Country,
   Jazz, Classical
• Plenty of new songs


Anyone can attend and you don't need to attend all the sessions.  A new breakthrough approach, allows each session to be complete even for people who have no experience playing the guitar. 


And after your lesson, hang out and meet people, or go check out the sights in the Park!!

• Bring your own guitar for these lessons
• Bring a portable music stand if you have one
• Also bring a notepad and a pencil


IN CASE OF RAIN:
If it rains, or there's a threat of rain (including if there is rain the night before or in the early morning and the ground is left soggy), we will have the meetup at an indoor location; check the meetup group announcements for update if looks like rain...the alternate location we will meet at is:

The Sony Public Atrium (see image below)
550 Madison Avenue, NY, NY  10022
Enter on 55th Street, and look for the guitars gathered near the Starbucks to the right of the entrance.

Remember: please update your RSVP if your plans change and you are unable to make it.  If something changes the day of the meetup, please let me know by phone or text at[masked]-1031.

results.description:
Walk-and-Eat West Greenwich Village
Walk-and-Eat in a West Greenwich Village Tour made popular for its authentic bohemian history. You will find famous places where celebrities of 20th century liked to come for a cup of coffee and chat with friends and acquaintances. These places still exist and are open to all and every visitor who comes to the Village. Woody Allen, Andy Warhol, Valery Solanas, John Tyler, Jackson Pollock, Eugene O`Neill, Charlie Chaplin, Gregory Corso, Bob Dylan, Lawrence Ferlinghetti, Allen Ginsberg, LeRoi Jones, Jack Kerouac,Ray Bremser, Jimi Hendrix, Bruce Springsteen, The Velvet Underground, Cat Mother & the All Night Newsboys, Kool and the Gang, Peter, Paul & Mary, Lenny Bruce, Joan Rivers and many more- feel like a part of New York Bohemia. There is no other place like New York. This tour will include the sample of authentic New York style food such as pizza, falafel, riceballs and more.
Washington Square
New York University
New York Authentic Food
Musicians memorable places
"Friends" Building
"Stonewall Inn" Riot and mor This tour takes approximately two hours and is easily accessible for baby strollers and wheelchairs.
results.name: Walk-and -Eat West Village Walking Tour

results.description:
Have you ever wanted to know what E = mc^2 means?  How Einstein shook up up Physics (and the world) by ridding it of the notion of absolute space and time?  Wondered why nothing can travel faster then the speed of light?  These questions, and Einstein's beautifully simple answers to them, really sparked my initial interest in physics. I have never really tired of returning to them.

Join us for a discussion of how Einstein arrived at his theory from first principles.  We will talk about the relativity of simultaneity, how velocities add in a relativistic framework, introduce Minkowski space and derive the Lorentz transformation between different inertial frames of reference.  There will be some math involved, but not too heavy....vector and matrix multiplication is about all that we will need.

This is really a 2 parter, so we will go as far as time (in our meet-up frame of reference!) allows and then pick up next time.

Some good sources....

https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Introduction_to_special_relativity


Susskind's lectures ( which I think is a great starting point)...the first of which is here...

https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=toGH5BdgRZ4 


For the more adventurous...or, for those with more time on their hands

http://cosmo.nyu.edu/hogg/sr/sr.pdf
results.name: Discuss Einstein's Theory of Special Relativity

Rick will be holding down the July 14 Rise n Grind (Mark will be out of town). Classes will be on a hiatus from July 15-27 and will resume their normal schedule Tuesday, July 28. 

Every Saturday we host our weekend calisthenics training class.  This class focuses on building a solid foundation in the basics through fun and demanding routines as well as progressions towards advanced movements and techniques. The group setting adds further challenges to the workout while offering encouragement, motivation, and camaraderie between everyone involved.


Walk ups always welcome, RSVP's appreciated ;)

$20.00 per person

results.description:
https://d3mjyf8rb023qs.cloudfront.net/api/file/kV4c3ERMQE2CNwdoxBC9

Join us as we explore what was once the playgrounds of all things gang and mob related on this 2.5 hour walking tour. Stroll through historic downtown neighborhoods as you peer into their dark past. Visit famous sites of killings, movies, and infamous crimes. 

 Peer into New York's dark past and uncover hidden secrets when you visit places ruled by some of the city's most powerful gangs and mobs. Head to Little Italy, once the heart of a tight community of Italian immigrants, to hear stories about mob activities and visit notorious spots. You’ll also explore the little-known history of the Chinese migration to New York, and the dominance of dangerous street gangs and underground opium dens, as well as the ruthless gangs in the infamous Five Points area, and what became of them. Along the way you’ll stop to see historic sites, sample the local fare and discover hidden stories waiting to be revealed.

More info and tickets here - </a><a href="https://goo.gl/fTn5WQ">https://goo.gl/fTn5WQ
results.name: Discover the Gangs and Mobs of Old NYC!

Outdoor meetups are free, we play outside in a public park

Once you enter the park on 72nd and Riverside Drive, continue walking towards the river (pass the Dog Run), go down the stairs, and the courts are to the left underneath the highway.

results.description:
Find your perfect half playing the chess -literally!

If you are excited to try new things, if you love playing chess or you want to learn how to play, and if you are looking forward to socialising at the same time, you are looking at the right group! 

We are going to play chess a little different than the usual; 

- There will be only HALF of the chess sets (meaning that everyone will get half of the board and one side of the chess pieces). 


- Finding your other half among your group mates will be your job! 

It is a great way to socialise and meet new people who share the same passion you have: playing chess. If you don't know how to play, no worries, you'll meet with someone who will be willing to help you out -or we will!

Join us if you are ready to play chess, break the ice, and form meaningful connections!
results.name: Play Chess & Socialise the Creative Way!

results.description:
Ayaka Nishi Jewelry School is a private jewelry school that is in the private studio of a jewelry artist. 

You can make a jewelry by yourself at Ayaka Nishi Jewelry Design School in East Village. 
We provide semi-private classes with a small number of only four students per class. 
We offer One day class which is an experience for people who want to learn jewelry making. This also can be a perfect memory of New York City trip for visitors. Under the guidance of the teacher, you will create a ring and set a diamond for 3~4 hours. It is possible to engrave your initials and a date to make this piece an original.

Also, we offer beginner's course of all 12 sessions, wax course, such as free production class, depending on the purpose. 
For a student with no experience of jewelry production, I will teach you carefully from scratch. 
Would you like to partake in jewelry making fun together in an artistic space in a home-like environment?

Reserve Your Spot Today! https://goo.gl/KLq9Lu

20% Off Code: HISUMMER

meta.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window  is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
